page.title: 14LANGUAGE AND DIALECT
page.content: DURING THE LAST 20 YEARS MANY NEWCOMERS HAVE MOVED INTO THE AREA HENCE THERE ARE A GREAT VARIETY OF ACCENTS SPOKEN BUT STANDARD ENGLISH IS PREDOMINANT. THE ONLY WELSH SPOKEN IS BY INCOMERS, APPROXIMATELY TWO HOUSEHOLDS. THERE IS NO STRONGLY DEFINED ACCENT, NO DIALECT SPOKEN ALTHOUGH THE DUAL INFLUENCES OF THE HEREFORDSHIRE AND WELSH ACCENTS ARE DISCERNIBLE. THE SOFT ROLLING 'R' FAMILIAR IN HEREFORDSHIRE DIALECT IS HEARD AND SING-SONG WELSH INFLEXION IS EVIDENT. MANY OLD FARMING TERMS ARE STILL IN USE ALTHOUGH ON THE WANE; THE MOST COMMON BEING:- FOLLET - LOFT (POSSIBLY A CORRUPTION OF THE WELSH TAFLOD), GLAT - A HOLE IN A HEDGE, BUDGE - TO FILL A GAP, POO-EY, POO-EY - TO CALL COWS. PITCH IS USED TO DESCRIBE A SHORT STEEP HILL E.G.MYNACHDY PITCH.
